application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Background: Wide-ranging psychiatric assessments may improve patient outcomes when their results inform treatment decision-making. Specifically, symptoms relevant to diverse disorders may be expeditiously alleviated when etiology is correctly identified at outset. This study aimed to evaluate how MindMetrix, a wide-ranging statistic-driven assessment, affected the trajectory of symptom improvement in patients at a large outpatient center. Methods: In this retrospective, pretest-postest non-equivalent study, all patients who initiated treatment at Rochester Center for Behavioral Medicine completed an intake appointment before being assigned to take MindMetrix (n = 97) or commencing treatment without additional assessment (n = 50). Before every visit, patients took a pre-visit survey, which included the Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ)-9 Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD) scale-2, and the ADHD Symptom and Side Effect Tracking Scale (ASSET). To determine whether MindMetrix adjusted symptom improvement over time, moderation analyses with time in treatment, MindMetrix assignment, and an interaction term examined the interactive effect on PHQ-9, GAD-2, or ASSET scale scores. This analysis included all patient visits after they began treatment at RCBM. Results: The moderation analyses found improvements in PHQ-9, GAD-2, and ASSET scales as patients proceeded through treatment, independently of their MindMetrix assignment. On the PHQ-9 and ASSET, MindMetrix significantly adjusted the effect of time in treatment, suggesting accelerated improvement. Conclusions: Results suggest that MindMetrix is an effective tool that can be used to guide early clinical decisions. Improvements seen in patients who took the MindMetrix assessment support its clinical benefit and potential for broad application in behavioral health and primary care centers.

div.head: Background:
div.p: Despite high rates of mental health disorders in Western nations like the United States, it is estimated that approximately half of patients with a mental health condition go undiagnosed, and at least 65% are misdiagnosed. [1,2] Psychiatric diagnosis is complicated by high rates of comorbidity amongst disorders and overlapping symptoms between distinct disorders. [3] Patients are typically referred to specialty care after consulting their primary care doctor, but validated screening tools are underutilized and may overlook comorbid disorders, delaying accurate diagnosis and leaving patients untreated for longer than necessary. [4][5][6] Additionally, patients may not have the tools to accurately communicate their symptoms, and they may be hesitant to disclose their experiences because of perceived stigma. [5] Given the high rates of undiagnosed and misdiagnosed conditions, [1,2] and given that early intervention is one of the strongest predictors of positive outcomes of psychiatric disorders, [7,8] it is imperative to develop comprehensive assessment tools to facilitate accurate diagnosis in primary and specialty care.

MindMetrix is a, statistics-driven, comprehensive assessment tool, boasting a unique method of administrating relevant sets of pre-existing self-report scales to screen across more than 53 different categories of mental health conditions, including common symptom patterns carrying cross-diagnostic relevance (e.g., depressive episode features, anxious thoughts and feelings, and executive function dysregulation). [9] The platform incorporates well-known and validated psychological rating scales in alignment with DSM-5 criteria. Each condition is evaluated based on responses to a set of rating scales specific to the condition, and responses are weighted according to the published sensitivity and specificity of each particular scale and their designated clinical cutoff score. With this method, no single measure determines the outcome of the assessment, but, rather, all responses are considered in the context of the full set of tests. Responses to the MindMetrix questions guide the results, ultimately reporting a likelihood for each screened-for disorder's presence in relation to general population prevalence rates. Likelihoods are calculated using the test results (positive or negative), published accuracy rates of each test, and the prevalence of each condition in the U.S. adult population.

Hypotheses created by the questions inform which sets of validated measures to administer next for additional screening. The comprehensive approach that MindMetrix brings to psychological testing has the potential to be highly valuable to patients and clinicians, but the benefits of such an approach to patient treatment outcomes have not yet been investigated.

The current study evaluates the effects of incorporating MindMetrix into psychiatric intake on patient outcomes at variable times post-intake. The analysis aims to determine whether patients who were assigned MindMetrix upon intake to Rochester Center for Behavioral Medicine (RCBM) demonstrated improvements in self-and clinician-reported symptomology compared to patients who were not assigned MindMetrix. Depression, anxiety, and ADHD symptoms were used as the outcome measures on which to assess general improvements, regardless of the diagnosed condition. Depression and anxiety have been identified as core behavioral health measures and are generally recommended for screening in primary care because they are among the most common mental health conditions. [10,11] Given that ADHD has profound impacts on quality of life, and many adults are not diagnosed or receiving treatment, more professionals are advocating for increased adult screening for ADHD. [12,13] Together, changes in depressive, anxiety, and ADHD symptoms provide valuable insight to the patients' wellbeing. Results have the potential to support the widespread use of MindMetrix in clinical practice to help guide diagnosis of a broad range of mental health disorders.

div.head: Methods:
div.p: Participants and study design This study was a retrospective, pretest-postest non-equivalent group design.

Participants included in the analysis were adults (≥18 years; age: M ± SD = 35.82 ± 13.09 years old) who started treatment at RCBM between October 2023 and June 2024. The majority of participants were female (67.12%) and identified as white (86.3%), with 6.85% identifying as Black, 4.11% as Hispanic, and 1.4% as Asian or other. Patients must have had a clinicianassessed Clinical Global Improvement-Severity (CGI-S) [14] rating of at least four at their initial visit, indicating moderate symptom severity, and must have visited with a prescriber for medication management. All patients completed an intake appointment, after which their clinician evaluated whether they would benefit from further psychological testing and assigned them to take the MindMetrix assessment on a case-by-case basis. The analysis included 97 patients who were assigned to take the MindMetrix assessment and 50 patients who proceeded through RCBM intake procedures, including a clinical interview and no other up-front assessments. Patients who were assigned MindMetrix (+MM) did not score differently from those who were not assigned MindMetrix (-MM) on self-report psychological questionnaires completed during the pre-visit survey or clinician-assessed symptom severity ( Table 1) Patients initiating treatment at RCBM did so either via self referral or referral from a mental health and medical provider. Before their intake appointment and each subsequent appointment, patients completed a pre-visit survey through Qualtrics, an online survey distribution software connected with RCBM's electronic charting program through the Qualtrics API. This system connects the patients' data with their medical history and clinician assessments for the clinician to review prior to each visit.

div.head: Variables
div.p: The pre-visit surveys screened for depression, anxiety, and ADHD using the Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ)-9, [15] Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD) scale-2, [16] and the ADHD Symptom and Side Effect Tracking Scale (ASSET), respectively. [17] The PHQ-9 is a nineitem self-report tool used to screen for depression by indicating symptom severity, with responses scored from 0 ("not at all") to 3 ("nearly every day") with a maximum total score of 27.

It has demonstrated good psychometric values in various settings, with a score of 10 or higher indicating likely depression. [18] The GAD-2 is a shortened version of the GAD-7, a seven-item scale for screening GAD, using two core anxiety questions rated from 0 ("not at all") to 3 ("nearly every day"). It has demonstrated validity and reliability, with a cutoff score of 3 or higher indicating likely anxiety. [19] The ASSET is a 10-item self-report tool for assessing ADHD symptom severity with a companion list of assorted side effects. It has two subscales:

Inattentive (e.g., attention span, forgetfulness) and Hyperactivity/Impulsivity (e.g., fidgetiness, mood). The scale uses a 6-point severity rating (1 = no problem present; 6 = severe impact) and a factor score is calculated as a weighted sum of the ten severity items, with a cut-off of 4.40 indicating high sensitivity and specificity. The list of side effects (e.g., insomnia, dry mouth, tics)

is rated on a Likert scale from 1 ("never") to 5 ("always"). [17] Additionally, clinicians completed the Clinical Global Impressions-Severity (CGI-S) scale for patients at each visit to determine whether quantitative measurements taken during treatment visits reflect changes in treatment response for the patients. [14] The CGI, which includes three components assessing Severity of Illness (CGI-S), Global Improvement (CGI-I),

and Efficacy Index, was developed by the National Institute of Mental Health and has since become a standard tool in clinical practice. The CGI-S, used in the current study, rates illness severity on a 7-point scale from 1 ("normal") to 7 ("extremely ill"). It has proven useful in evaluating a variety of mental health conditions [20,21] and shows good validity [20,22] comparable to similar scales. [23] The PHQ-9, GAD-2, and ASSET are patient-rated scales, whereas the CGI-S is a clinician-rated scale.

A change variable for each scale score was calculated for every patients' first visit, if any, that occurred at least 90 days after their initial visit. The change score was the difference between the score after at least 90 days and the initial score.

div.head: Results:
div.p: To first explore the overall associations between MindMetrix, time in treatment, and scores on PHQ-9, GAD-2, and ASSET scales, correlations were computed between all variables. This demonstrated significant relationships between MindMetrix and PHQ-9, GAD-2, and ASSET scores. The number of days in treatment only correlated with the PHQ-9 score (Table 2).

To determine the effects of MindMetrix on PHQ-9, GAD-2, and ASSET scores at a discrete time point, one-way ANOVAs were conducted with patients' change scores from their first visit that fell between 90 days and 120 days since their initial visit. This was done to approximate similar lengths of time in treatment for all patients. There was no effect of MindMetrix on the change in PHQ-9 (F1,112 = 2.070, p = .153) or ASSET scores (F1,103 = 1.922, p = .169), but patients assigned to MindMetrix had a greater reduction in GAD-2 than those who were not (F1,111 = 12.147, p = .034).

To explore the hypothesis that the level of symptom improvement as time in treatment progresses is significantly affected by whether a patient was assigned to take MindMetrix, these analyses were followed up with moderation analyses. Moderation analyses demonstrated that with more time in treatment, depressive, anxiety and ADHD symptoms were significantly improved. Being assigned MindMetrix was significantly associated with lower scores on PHQ-9, overall. For the PHQ-9 and ASSET, both significantly impacted by time, the interaction term of MindMetrix and days since initial visit was also significant, indicating that the relationship between treatment time and symptom improvement depended on whether MindMetrix was included in the patient's treatment (Table 3). These interactions were visualized using plots of PHQ-9, and ASSET scores as a function of the number of days since the patients' initial visit, separated by the factor of MindMetrix assignment (Figure 1a-b). Table 2. Pearson correlations between MindMetrix assignment, days in treatment, and PHQ-9, GAD-2, and ASSET scores at visits between 90 and 120 days since the initial visit.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: This study is the first to empirically demonstrate the benefits of including MindMetrix, a comprehensive mental health assessment, in the standard intake protocol for patients referred for mental health treatment. Being assigned to MindMetrix was correlated with improvements in PHQ-9, GAD-2, and ASSET scores over the patients' first three months in treatment at RCBM.
For PHQ-9, the amount of time in treatment was also correlated with symptom improvements.

PHQ-9 was significantly correlated with GAD-2 and ASSET, and ASSET was significantly correlated with GAD-2. The interrelatedness of the three assessments aligns with welldocumented studies showing high comorbidity of depression and anxiety with ADHD, [24][25][26][27] and between depression and anxiety. [28] Indeed, most patients with ADHD have at least one comorbid psychiatric condition, with anxiety and mood disorders representing the most common coexisting conditions. [26] It was expected that most patients would show improved symptoms as treatment time increased, in line with previous reports that longer treatment duration results in more positive outcomes. [29][30][31] To delineate the effect of MindMetrix from the effect of time in treatment, the moderation analysis showed that PHQ-9, GAD-2, and ASSET scores improved with more time and comorbidity. There is also evidence that patients are more satisfied with mental health care that includes shared decision making processes, [32] and comprehensive assessments appear to meet patients' needs in this area. [1,33] Future studies analyzing clinicians' and patients' perceptions of MindMetrix, including their satisfaction with intake procedures that include MindMetrix, will help clarify why patients who took MindMetrix show an accelerated rate of improvement.

The results of this study are limited by its retrospective observational design. Without a prospective experimental design, the timing and number of follow-up visits were not consistent between patients. Also, many patients did not receive extended treatment for longer than four months, so long-term results cannot be assessed from the present results. Additionally, factors that could affect outcomes, including the type of treatment patients received and their initial diagnosis, were not included in the analyses. Despite its limitations, as a first proof-of-concept study, MindMetrix is shown to be beneficial to patients. It will be worthwhile to explore potential reasons why patients who take MindMetrix experience accelerated symptom improvement.
Given the known importance of early, accurate diagnoses in improving treatment outcomes,

MindMetrix was designed to guide clinicians in their early response to patients at intake. The above results suggest that MindMetrix is an innovative approach to psychological testing that has the potential to be highly valuable to patients and clinicians. The present findings support the potential benefits of MindMetrix and should encourage providers to consider its incorporation into their practice.

figure.figDesc: . The number of follow-up visits did not differ between the +MM group (nvisits = 567, M = 11.20, SD = 11.93) and -MM group (nvisits = 282, M = 11.94, SD = 8.712), t(842) = -0.196, p = .36. On average, follow-up visits occurred 7.64 days closer to the initial visit in the -MM group (M = 73.26, SD = 38.23) compared to the +MM group (M = 80.90, SD = 40.13), t(842) = 2.639, p = .008, representing an overall small effect size (d = 0.193).

Statistical AnalysisStatistical analyses were conducted with IBM ® SPSS ® Statistics 30.0 (Armonk, New York, USA). Correlation and moderation analyses aimed to determine the effect of MindMetrix on the outcome scores of each scale (PHQ-9, GAD-2, and ASSET), particularly whether MindMetrix significantly adjusted symptom improvement over time.First, correlation analyses were conducted to determine associations between time in treatment, MindMetrix, and scores on each scale (PHQ-9, GAD-2, ASSET, and CGI-S). This was to test the initial hypothesis that overall, time in treatment and MindMetrix are associated with symptom improvement.Next, to test whether symptom changes were affected by MindMetrix, a one-way ANOVA was conducted with MindMetrix assignment as the between-subject factor and the change variable for each score after 90 days as the dependent variable. Score changes at 90 days were used because follow-up data had been collected for 64% of patients between 90 and 120 days from their initial visit, whereas fewer than 50% of patients had follow-up data after four months.To account for every patient having a different amount of time between visits, and to include patients who had multiple follow-up visits, moderation analyses were conducted. For each outcome scale, regression models were built with time in treatment and MindMetrix assignment as the quasi-independent variables and the PHQ-9, GAD-2, or ASSET scale score as the dependent variable. The time in treatment and MindMetrix predictors were centered around zero. An interaction term between the time in treatment and MindMetrix assignment was added to the model to determine whether MindMetrix adjusts the effect of time in treatment on outcome scores. For patients with more than one follow-up visit, the moderation analyses treated every visit's outcome score as a separate data point.

figure.head: Table 3 .
figure.figDesc: Results of moderation analyses of the effect of time in treatment and MindMetrix assignment on PHQ-9, GAD-2, and ASSET scores. Symptom and Side Effect Tracking Scale; GAD-2, Generalized Anxiety Disorder-2; MM, MindMetrix; PHQ-9, Patient Health Questionnaire-9.

figure.head: Figure 1 .
figure.figDesc: Plots of the interaction between time in treatment and MindMetrix on patients' scores on PHQ-9 (a) and ASSET (b). MindMetrix adjusts the level of symptom reduction as patients progress through treatment.

in treatment, and MindMetrix accelerated the effect of time in treatment on symptom improvement for PHQ-9 and ASSET scores. In contrast, GAD-2 scores were not independently improved by MindMetrix, and MindMetrix did not adjust the relationship between treatment time and symptom improvement. This could be indicative of a floor effect, where patients are demonstrating strong reductions in anxiety regardless of MindMetrix assignment. Importantly, results of the ANOVA showed that the change in anxiety, only considering the first visit after 90 days of treatment, revealed significant improvements in patients who took MindMetrix. Therefore, it is possible that the effects of MindMetrix are acute and could be masked by modeling the relationship linearly over a longer period of treatment. Additionally, other patient factors could be mediating the effects of MindMetrix on anxiety, which should be explored in future studies. Although the results show that MindMetrix leads to improvements in depression, anxiety, and ADHD, the precise means by which this occurs cannot be interpreted from the present analyses and should be a focal point of future studies. When patients take MindMetrix, their providers gain access to a detailed outline of their likelihood of scoring above the clinical cutoffs for over 50 disorders. It is possible that with more information about their patients, clinicians are better informed to make appropriate treatment plans in line with the patients' most likely diagnoses. Instead of administering specific assessments for suspected disorders, they are equipped with insights within a framework of several disorders, accounting for symptom overlap

figure.head: Table 1 .
figure.figDesc: Baseline psychological assessments from the pre-visit survey and clinician assessment at the initial visit. Qualtrics electronic storage system. Pharmacy data was sent and received through the SureScripts system. All queried information was housed in RCBM's Qualtrics platform. No accessing of the patient's chart or the EMRs system was required to compile the study datasheet. No columns on this data sheet contained any of the 18 identifiers described in the HIPAA privacy rule's safe harbor provision, ensuring that, to the furthest extent possible, no reidentification of a patient would be possible. The study staff responsible for compiling the datasheet did not retain any records of patient identifiers that may have been consulted in the construction of the study datasheet. No
figure.note: ASSET, ADHD Symptom and Side Effect Tracking Scale; CGI-S, Clinical Global Improvement- Severity; GAD-2, Generalized Anxiety Disorder-2; MM, MindMetrix; PHQ-9, Patient Health Questionnaire-9.a For CGI-S, n = 50 in the -MM group. Procedures Electronic medical records (EMRs) were obtained from RCBM, a large outpatient psychiatric practice, which maintains a HIPAA-compliant Qualtrics platform for securely administering patient-facing forms, questionnaires, and psychometrics. Data were de-identified by compiling the elements onto a single datasheet as they were retrieved via direct queries to the electronic medical records system's Server and queries to the practice'sre-identification of a patient was attempted or permitted by the study researchers.

div.head: Acknowledgments
div.p: The authors would like to thank the staff at RCBM for their support and the patients whose data are included in these analyses.

div.head: Ethics approval and consent to participate
div.p: The research presented in this manuscript has received ethics approval from Oakland University Institutional Review Board (IRB). All methods were performed in accordance with the ethical standards laid down in the 1964 Declaration of Helsinki and its later amendments. All participants involved in this study provided informed consent and gave permission for their deidentified data to be used in undisclosed future research prior to their participation, and secondary research use of their information was deemed ethical by the responsible IRB.

div.head: Consent for publication
div.p: Patients gave written consent for data publication.

div.head: Competing interests
div.p: The authors declare that they have no competing interests.

div.head: Availability of data and materials
div.p: The datasets used in the current study are available from the corresponding author upon reasonable request.

div.head: Funding
div.p: The authors have no funding information to report.

Authors' contributions J.Y., J.S., R.P., and M.N. conceptualized the study. R.P., A.P., L.W, and L.G. designed and performed statistical analyses and acquired regulatory approval. L.G. wrote the initial draft and edited the manuscript. All authors reviewed and edited the manuscript.
